commentBody: I had VAX for "shots" and spent forever on that SW corner. Gah. But what an excellent puzzle!
Really liked the theme. And nice to see the Midi make a reappearance!
Great theme, thanks.
A very clever puzzle this one.  Fun with ROMANNUMERALS and clever wordplay too.  VIKINGSHIPS was the last themer I got, and my favorite of the bunch BYGUM.
Great puzzle. Had a lot of fun figuring out the theme entries. And, for me at least, an appropriate level of difficulty for a Thursday.
Wow, that was hard to suss out the theme!  But it's cute, that's for sure. I've never been sure what a ream is. "What is a ream?", I in quire.
Bring on the SNOW! That was great.  Very clever, solvable, made me think, learned something new, used something old, and very well done, if all told
Where was the rebus?
I have no idea what a rebus is. When posting a puzzle could you indicate that it is some kind of hybrid and not a straight crossword?
Oof my brain resisted this one, but was satisfying when it all came together! (With, admittedly, some light googling and a total guess in a couple of places.) thanks for a fun puzzle!

Super.  Was stuck for a minute with 65A but then counted the symbols and it fell right into place.

As an aside, I've never been able to remember L and D: which one is 50 and which one is 500.

Brilliant! A perfect Thursday puzzle. Loved the theme, the cluing, and the satisfying AHA when it came together.

Especially liked Viking ships and X Boxes !

Well done, and congrats on the NYT debut. This is how it's done.
I loved this puzzle! Fun play from start to finish.
Tomorrow‚Äôs Midi completed ‚Äì timer is stopped and colored circles appeared confirming solve ‚Äì but puzzle does not show as completed on the main screen. Frustrating.

It was a nice touch that the entries still spelled legitimate words too. I appreciate that attention to detail ‚Äì it makes the puzzle feel more creative / well thought out.
Fun one.

Fun puzzle!  I liked how the theme answers were still valid words that had nothing to do with the clue; it was actually helpful even though I forgot a bit of roman numeration.  Like "X"boxes made more sense than "V"boxes.
Ah, so there's a MIDI crossword now. Does this mean I need to plug in my digital piano and play notes instead of pressing my laptop keyboard to solve it?

I solve in the Android app, and there's no Midi puzzle on my phone. Do I have to do an update or something? I'm pretty sure Pips just appeared without me doing anything, so why would this be different?
I adored this puzzle. It was a rough start, but things came together after I figured out the theme. A favorite, for sure.

Impressive debut. Well thought out and executed theme. üëèüèºüëèüèºüëèüèº I figured out the revealer right away which helped me solve each themer. Impressed that LIABILITIES was 51A. I had to explain to my friends that it meant call 9-1-1 ü§¶üèº‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è. Here‚Äôs the clip: https://youtu.be/0teQe1BYBpM?si=2JOI0cuc8IQB_YwF Thank you, Yitzi. I look forward to seeing more of your work!!
Delightful!

Finally a Thursday puzzle that made me think a bit for the reward of finishing it!  I wish it was a little harder... I still feel like finishing a Thursday in under 15 minutes is a very quick solve.  (sigh...wistfully remembering the days when Thursday puzzles took at least 20-30 minutes to finish...)
Really fun puzzle.  Thought I wasn‚Äôt going to get there, and yet it came BYGUM.

Really enjoyed the theme, but it was a slow one for me. I had never heard of 52D, and the shapes in 65A weren‚Äôt italicised (at least on my phone?) so I didn‚Äôt realise that was a themed clue until the very end

Congratulations Yitzi on your debut! I hope you become famous enough that we can start to use your name in crossword puzzles!
I‚Äôll be honest I haven‚Äôt been as torn about a Thursday puzzle in a long time. On the one hand I liked the theme idea overall and that even once you got the theme, there was a fair challenge to get the themers, either because you had to do math (yay, I‚Äôm with you, sorry not sorry) or because you don‚Äôt know off-hand the number of Georgian Kings, angles in a chiliagon, or sheets in a ream (CREAMS? DREAMS?). But I HATED the clue for the revealer (and that‚Äôs on the editors). I would say most people seeing X and XL would immediately think ROMANNUMERALS as clued before shirt sizes so that just gave away the trick immediately. Why ruin a perfectly good clever theme with such a straightforward revealer?

I was also torn by a lot of the clues. I thought the grid was very decent especially for a debut so kudos on that. Plus it‚Äôs a pangram has anyone mentioned that?And I liked a lot of the clues‚Äîthe SIMILE and PLURAL ones, the twin curry clues, and several others. On the other hand, I wasn‚Äôt a fan of UNNAILED as an entry, especially next to what  I thought was a bit awkward clue for GAINTIME. And while I didn‚Äôt think the overall challenge was egregious today, there were still just too many unnecessary gimmes. ‚ÄúLong tongued animal‚Äù for ANTEATER on a Thursday? Come on, editors, we can do better!

Still, great debut, fun overall, and I look forward to more from you!
C% enjoyable.
Really can‚Äôt get into this one. We get it, you‚Äôre smart‚Ä¶oh well. Can‚Äôt win em all.

The writer of the column is obviously having a very bad day, though. The obvious disdain for this fun and interesting puzzle ‚Äî and the whole spiel about it being a rebus, when this is not generally what most puzzlers would call a rebus anyway ‚Äî is very off-putting.

Great puzzle, like the added touch of Mercury/Hermes. And very clever with the roti vs rice dilemma. Putting this one on my POY list for sure! And Yitzi Snow, what a great name. Like a character in a Philip Roth novel. So cool. 

Yeah, I looked up chiliagon to see what it looked like, and weirdly, all the chiliagons I came across looked like straight-up circles !(probably up close it would look like a bike gear)

And I also like the druggy trinity of opiates, aptly leading to a droopy repose.  Also to match word lengths in the themers (which were all placed symmetrically), that takes some real craft. 

Word of the Month: JIG
51A being LIABILITIES is pretty neat. Lovely Thursday.

I had to come to the column for help, but two words were all it took for everything to fall into place.  I seemed to hear an astral hum when it was done.

A beautiful puzzle, Yitzi, one that was a triumph to construct.  Congratulations on your debut.

commentBody:
And the Times puzzle editor said unto them, Fear not: for, behold, I bring you good tidings of great joy, which shall be to all people. For unto you is born this day a Thursday puzzle worthy of Thursday.

Big shout out to Mr. Snow for (at least temporarily) restoring my faith in the quality here.

And a big shout out to Sam for referencing Bartleby, my vote for the finest short story ever written.

Ah, Sam!  Ah, humanity!

Since I figured out the trick immediately with 1A. I was sad to see such a literal revealer.  
I thought. ‚ÄúWell that‚Äôs the gateway to, ‚Äòtoo easy!‚Äô‚Äù
Then again. I immediately cracked the top corner thanks to the classic CONAIR.  

I guess we‚Äôll see. 
LIabilities was inspired. 
Dreams was too funny. 

But fun concept and great execution. 
Congrats Yitzi.

Wow. There is another daily puzzle now?
And each puzzle is titled?  

Don‚Äôt understand the need for a MIDI but fun to have. Grow that audience guess. 

Can‚Äôt wait for ‚Äúthat Friday MIDI felt like a MINI Tuesday‚Äù comments.

Unfortunately picked up the trick on 1A, which was helpful for the rest of the themers, but also made it a little too easy.

Nevertheless, it was fun to get through, and it was nice that the themers were real words or things and not nonsense as sometimes happens. Did have a few answers that required crosses, and had to make one correction at the end.

Congrats on the debut, and hope to see more from you, Yitzi! Thanks!
Let the "Is it a rebus puzzle?" debate begin!

Not the most familiar with ‚ÄúBy Gum‚Äù and the fact  ‚ÄúVangles, Mangles, Dangles, Bangles‚Äù all worked wasn‚Äôt helpful!

Fun puzzle.  Figured the play with ‚ÄúConAir, Nae, Hit, and ENE‚Äù and the puzzle opened up a bit. Thanks for an interesting Thursday!

commentBody:
65A earns my vote for cleverest clue of the year to date.

It took me several minutes to understand it even after solving the puzzle.  (Which of course is not unusual.)

I had no idea that when you italicize boxes they become rhombi.

And so, upon initial and subsequent hand-to-hand engagements with the clue, had no idea the clue was either italicized or consisted of boxes.

Only after I counted them, several minutes after solving and  after confirming, as usual, that the Word Play writer did not share my belief that this was a Tricky Clue - why does this happen like ALL the time?! - did it click.

Brilliant!

(Or I'm just a dolt.)
I thought today's puzzle was fun! Something different and clever. Dreams and liabilities were great. Kudos to the creator on their debut. Well done!

‚ù§Ô∏è cryptics
‚ù§Ô∏è nyt thursdays
‚ù§Ô∏è this debut puzzle! 

Please make many more! The trickier and math-ier the better.
Clever, fun, not too easy. Thanks. üòä

The day after one of my worst crossword experiences, Yitzi Snow delivers one of my favorites. The wordplay in the basic clues is solid and amusing, but the "rebus" (thankfully not using the execrable "Rebus" function became clear quickly, and was fun to play with.

Somehow, after fighting with the February 25 puzzle for literal hours across three separate software platforms and two devices, I managed to maintain my streak. As long as there's a steady stream of puzzles like today's, I may even someday forgive the design department for yesterday's disaster.
The boxes in the clue didn't look italicized to me ... Great puzzle though

"I plan to visit the Sistine Chapel."
"Rome is where the art is!"

("I know! I've just got a good ceiling about it.")
Not happy with my performance on this one.  Much slower than my average.  Little joy on completion, just frustration at being so dense.  At least I didn't have to look anything up.  Barely.  ;-(

I can see the antinumerists possibly having objections but  I found it to be a very nice puzzle. üëçüòÄ The calories clue was clunky ‚Äî amount of an energy unit  ‚Äî ü´§ 

A little bit of mental arithmetic, a little bit of knowledge about units, and TWOD for plane elicited a smile.  

Thanks to the setter and congratulations on an excellent debut.
VI kingships for the win!

Fantastic puzzle! Made my brain hurt in the best possible way. Loved the AHA moment when the theme came together. I stared at MANGLES (the first theme entry i got with crosses) for the longest time before it clicked. And then the others fell into place beautifully. VIKINGSHIPS and LIABILITIES made me laugh :) One of the most satisfyingly crunchy Thursday themes in a while!
As a non-US solver, I always struggle with how the clues 'dagnabbit', and 'bah', are used for any kind of backwater colloquialisms. Surely there are better clues to be had.
What a weird one! It felt tricky and somewhat more difficult than usual, and yet I shaved 25% off my Thursday average. Not sure how it worked out that way, but it was fun!

I for one, think this puzzle was excellent!

Congratulations on your debut, Yitzi, and please come back soon.
This puzzle made me smile. I loved it.
Brilliant innovation, and very fairly hinted at by the answer ‚ÄúRoman numerals‚Äù. Love your use of Roman math to adjust the ‚Äúrebus‚Äù, itself a Roman word. SPQR!

Wow I missed that all of the corner clues were italicised.

That really ruins the puzzle.

Maybe themes clues could always be highlighted in the app not just sometimes. The italics can be subtle.

Got the theme though... For the two italics I identified.

By gum?  That's not great.
I really likes this puzzle!  Challenging but solvable, with a clever theme and interesting takes on some of the clues.  Nice work!!

Congratulations on an artful and clever debut. It is so satisfying to see an innovative theme executed thoughtfully into a Thursday-like motif. The landmines were there and the fun (as always on a Thurs.) was to expose them without losing a leg!  So intuitive and universally literary to juxtapose Dickens‚Äô ‚Äúbah‚Äù with Shakespeare‚Äôs FIE. Loved it!

For today's Midi Puzzle's theme, I am reminded of one of my favourite neurodivergence puns, that never fails to make me chuckle and reminds me I am more than just my disability:

"Call me Roy G. Biv, because I am visibly on the spectrum." üåà

Great debut, Yitzi!  Just terrific.

I love to see new constructors, because you are our hope for future puzzles.

Even accounting for my sentimental affections for debuts, this was just terrific.  

I felt pleasantly engaged the whole time.

Two thumbs, WAY up!

I am so hoping you'll be willing to do hundreds of hours of work for virtually no pay per hour, in order to make me happy for 40 minutes.

After that last paragraph, I'm not feeling so good about myself right now, at this moment.

(since yesterday's Midi didn't really seem to appear for a lot of us until today)

I can't tell if it's someone sneaking in something clever, or an unintentional self-own, that a European filling in the first of the Midis would conclude that it's KIDSIZE.

When I was in the 3rd grade my teacher waited until 2:30 in the afternoon on a hot day to introduce us to Roman Numerals. My 8-year-old-mind was blown. To be fair to Mrs. Inman (may she rest in peace), she probably mentioned that while we did in fact have to learn Roman Numerals, we would really never have to use them. 

Until TODAY, that is! Thanks a lot, Yitzi. But congratulations on your debut.
What a cool puzzle‚Äîabsolutely loved it. Congratulations on your debut, Yitzi!
Well would you look at that, an excellent puzzle. Great balance of gimmes and thinkers, really needed some of those after a pretty blank first pass. More like this please!
The absolute and total best part of this crossword was - the lack of complaints, moans and protests about it. Thank goodness.
Amazing! The moment when it clicked (for me, VIKINGSHIPS) was magic. Congrats!

Very nice puzzle. Congrats Yitzi. 
I like the relative shift from obscure American trivia to a greater focus on wordplay. I often find myself having to look up random Oscar winners from the 60s or some niche art deco architect, but today all the trivia was very accessible.

55A and 47D made me smile when I got them.

Great puzzle, with a minor technical glitch:

On my iPad the clue for 65A was a row of squares, but on my phone (Android) it was a row of slanted squares (which I gather from the comments are meant to be italicized squares). They should have made sure that the clue was consistent across platforms.

I started the puzzle on my phone, and when I got to 65A I confidently entered RHOMBI. I eventually fixed it from the crossings, though I didn‚Äôt understand XBOXES until I read the comments.

Alternate clue for 35A

[L and M, but not N]

Great Thursday puzzle.  I got the revealer early  but I also struggled to 'find' the italicized clues. 1A and 65A most notably did not appear as italicised until i really zoomed in on my screen. A * or even highlighting all themed entries when on the revealer would have been better,

Wait, wait, I got one:

[1/2 a ton -1]

IMPOUNDS
I never comment, but thought I should make an exception for a great Thursday. Slower than usual for me, but very enjoyable!

Terrific debut, Yitzi!

Not only was the theme fun, but there was some great cluing as well, especially [Like cats and dogs] for PLURAL, [Stall, e.g,] for GAIN TIME and [Like a plane, informally] for TWO D.

I hope to see you back again and again.
What a great puzzle, and for me so much fun to get the theme (trick) before the hint!

Brian Eno did not make it into today's crossword, but I'd like to put in a word for the Gary Hustwit film about his art. If you have $15 and a couple of hours, I highly recommend catching one of the upcoming livestreams. There's only a 1 in 52 quintillion chance you'll see the same version I saw, but if you have an interest in creativity, I think you'll find it fascinating. There are 4 more opportunities to see it this week, and you can sign up at: https://www.chanceoperations.com/events For more information, see this NYT review: https://www.nytimes.com/2024/07/11/movies/eno-review-creativity-52-billion-billion-ways.html?unlocked_article_code=1.PFA.rZLO.4_3bP6_EdXZI&smid=url-share

The moment I saw the clue for 49D I was reminded of this visit on Conan: https://youtu.be/RAGcDi0DRtU?si=LLEmU-GbbA6ACezr My fellow Finn (and the Funniest Person in the World) Ismo talking about linguistics. And math. And @$$.
I agree with everyone today-a fun, challenging, clever puzzle. One quibble. Isn't "dagnabbit" an expression of irritation, while "by gum" is one more of resolve or determination?

Straying a bit from the great roman numerical nightmare of a rebus-though-non-rebus puzzle tonight....I liked it, I really did...

Though I am about as far north as I can be and still be in the continental United States, I was just pleasantly surprised, going out for a breath of air, with a late night, utterly gorgeous snow fall, as late as late February.

And I used to have to deal with snow in Tennessee in April.

But I'll take every snowfall I can get.  As long as I have my perfectly tailored walking stick that Lake Superior gave my grandson to give to me, I'm good in snow or shine.

They were boxes, but italicized. The boxes, the actual symbols for them, were italicized, and there were ten of them. I could stop wracking my brain for alternate ways of describing a series of parallelograms.

The moment I realized that I knew there was hope.

Wonderful puzzle, so clever and satisfying. All the theme material was excellent, but there was something particularly excellent about VIKINGSHIPS and its clue.

Thanks Yitzi, looking forward to more from you!
I'm dancing a JIG after solving this one.  That has appeared quite a bit recently,  hasn't it? Loved this puzzle.

Oi!

Scooted along,
all chuffed and saucy
until the SW grabbed 
CC's sass and began clobbering
it in true Whac-a-Mole fashion.

Parallelograms, grand SLAM,
not seeing the word *dozen*
in the LIABILITIES clue,

and set on reading [Vexing]
as alluring or seductive...

Oof.
Delete, delete delete!

Once it was empty,
and I gave up on what 
the *slanted* BOXES could be,

it was all good.

A most excellent debut, 
but a bona fide beauty 
of a puzzle
regardless.

Fantabulous.

Happy Thursday all!
The Friday of Fridays!
This was the hardest and most clever Thursday I've done in ages. It killed my time stats but I loved it. So well done!

Well.  There it is.  A quintessential Thursday.

Crafty theme, slippery and clever cluing, no-knows, all teaming up to create a riddle-fest.  Totally Thursday, IMO, in difficulty level and trickiness.

Marvelous concept!  For me, cracking it brought a very satisfying aha.

In the theme answers, I love how the marriage of Roman numerals and what they‚Äôre counting make legitimate words, so there‚Äôs no gibberish in the box.  

I liked seeing a clue that ended in ‚Äúe.g.‚Äù ‚Äì [Laudanum, e.g.] ‚Äì echoing Tuesday‚Äôs terrific E.G. puzzle.  I also liked the solving experience, a mix of quick-fill areas with brain-loving pesky ones.

Most impressive for a debut, Yitzi.  This was a wow.  What the heck can you follow it up with?  I can‚Äôt wait to see.  Thank you for a puzzle that filled me with GRINs!
Excellent theme! Even after getting the solver clue thought was required. Really enjoyed this one. What Thursday puzzles are supposed to be.
A lot of fun after figuring out the theme. I also loved VIkingships best. Didn't know what an iking ship was at first until I realized it was 6 and not 5.
Well done! Highly enjoyable.

Loved this puzzle.
My only hangup was with "CHILIAGON." I pictured a food truck serving Tex-Max fare: a "chiliwagon."

Turns out it's a thousand-sided polygon. Because it is visually indistinguishable from a circle, philosophers like Descartes used it to argue that imagination and pure intellect are distinct.
NOPE‚Ä¶if I wanted a math puzzle I would find one. Of course this was a debut. Ugh facepalm ‚Ä¶no thanks

What a wonderful puzzle. I struggled mightily until I figured out the theme. And for some reason I remembered that Nicholas Cage movie as 'Air-Con', which threw me off quite a bit. But I enjoyed this one a lot! A great sense of accomplishment when I finally finished!! Thank you!!

This may have been discussed in the past, but shouldn't MRS. have been listed as an abbreviation? It was the first thing that came into my mind when I read the clue, but figured it couldn't be that. Until it was.

Yes, there was math, but you also used (all the) letters. 

Loved this one. Fast for me.
Wow! What a great puzzle!

Hard to predict what the consensus will be regarding this one.

I got the theme immediately at 1A, and knowing the theme certainly helped me see VIKINGSHIPS, LIABILITIES and MANGLES. 

Was also impressed that LI-ABILITIES ended up at 51A!

Both liked and disliked the theme. The concept was clever, but several of the thematic clues seemed very forced simply to suggest a certain number of items. (I'm looking at you again, 51A!)

Some of the fill was also a bit ... strange: REDTIE, ICANSAY, UNNAILED (which, given the recent slides toward vulgarity in our puzzles, could have been clued as "Virginal" I suppose.)

On the whole, I liked this one. Took me 25 minutes, and I needed to think a lot despite knowing the theme. So a successful Thursday puzzle in my opinion. 

Congrats on the debut!

A grill is not a BBQ. unless you live on the East Coast. These are two fundamentally different cooking techniques for the rest of us. Grilling is hot and fast, BBQ is low and slow. You can't BBQ a hot dog, and you can't grill a brisket.
Loved it!  So clever and fun! Congrats Yitzi!

Love your Highland cow photo, Sam.
Fun theme. For some reason my brain did not register the boxes as being in italics so the SW corner was brutal.
Definitely unique and chewy! Quite surprised i finished it without help! *pats myself on the back*

Now THAT is a Thursday! I had a big grin on my face the whole time I was solving. Congrats on an excellent debut!

I will call this puzzle impossibly clever. I love the creativity of it, but it was well beyond my solving level. Or maybe I just didn‚Äôt have the patience for it today, even though ROMAN NUMERALS was one of the only answers I had after my first pass through the clues. But there were also lots of things I wasn‚Äôt familiar with. Genuinely happy all the diehards are happy today!

This was my favorite solve in quite a while! I loved the very Thursday theme, which did for me exactly what a theme is supposed to do in exactly the right order:

1. Confused but intrigued.
2. Halfway to filling in one of the trick answers, but not sure what comes next (51A)
3. Get one more piece for that answer and figure out the gimmick, allowing me to fill in the middle hint.
4. Use the gimmick to help with the remaining trick answers, which are still slightly tricky and not trivially easy.
5. Struggle with an especially tricky one which still has a satisfying solution (8A)

Well done, Yitzi Snow!
Wow, that was some very satisfying work to solve! Well done!
Great, great Thursday!  Tricky and challenging, without a lot of arcane trivia.  Well done!

Whew. And WOW! Typical slow start for me, but working out the reveal and finally catching on to the theme was a terrific 'aha' moment and also the key to working out the rest of the puzzle. Really amazing piece of construction too. And... of course my puzzle find today. A Saturday from May 30, 2009 by Matt Ginsberg. Not officially a themed puzzle but a rather interesting piece of construction with the focus on one letter. Some answers in that one: JACUZZI YITZHAK ZOG OZARK GINFIZZ ESTEVEZ SEIZING ZOOS PIZZAZZ BAZAARS ELZIE MAZY OOZED FEZ ZED and... AMAZING Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=5/30/2009&g=19&d=A ....

My favorite crossword in quite a while. Loved the theme, and that it added a bit of trivia on top of having to know which ROMAN NUMERALS fit in a particular answer. The SW gave me fits, as it took 15% of my total solve time to suss 53D, 55D, 56D and 57D‚Ä¶I sort of got stumped by 65A as the boxes didn‚Äôt seem italicized to me‚Ä¶but, then, how might one italicize boxes? Even so, I finished around 30% under my Thursday average. 

M congratulations to Yitzi Snow on a fine piece of work.
A rare case where I figured out the gimmick right away but still had to work. Excellent Thursday.
Easy theme, a couple tough ones.
Oh this was fantastic. I figured out the gimmick pretty quickly but was still thrown off, especially by ‚Äú250,000 sheets.‚Äù Kudos to the author!

Nice Thursday puzzle, Yitzi. (IMO, would have been better w/o the revealer‚Äîor just end the clue before the hint‚Äîbut it didn‚Äôt spoil it for me since I had fun sussing out 8‚Äô4‚Äù before I got there.) Hope for future puzzles from you, Yitzi, well done!

After I recovered from the revamped, vamped-up Puzzles intro page, I printed the "Yitzi Snow Special" and had myself some fun.  Hardest part?  Realizing that 1A was italicized.

So very enjoyable, especially with the "real words" aspect of the Themer entries.  BRAVA!!  More, please, Yitzy Snow!

commentBody:

One pet peeve of mine did appear again: the preposition meaning "up to" which is pronounced /t…™l/ is spelled [till]. Shortening [until] to ['til] is incorrect in the same way that it would be incorrect to shorten [unto] to ['to] instead of just writing [to].

I wonder if there was some era where parents were complaining about the lack of Roman numerals in education, the way people whine about their kids not knowing cursive. I certainly struggle with anything over XIII

The Day We Argued About Roman Numerals

that row remains VIVID ‚Äì

"Puzzles like this are why Thursday is my favorite puzzle day of the week.¬† This one will be added to my Puzzle of the Year list.¬† Do you have any idea how hard it is to come up with theme answers this good and this original?¬† I do -- because I had the exact same theme idea sometime within the past year.¬† After spending quite¬†a bit of time trying to dream up theme answers that were interesting without¬†being complete gibberish I decided to abandon the idea and come up with something else.¬† I never dreamed it could be made to work this well.¬†
¬†
VI (6) KINGSHIPS is the real highlight, of course.¬† I didn't see it at first; I kept wondering why on earth VIKING SHIPS was going to be the answer to this clue.¬† I certainly didn't want it to be.¬† And then, boom, it hit me.

Hats off, Yitzi!¬† This is so original and so well-executed.¬† I'm really impressed."

@JayTee

Putting anything other than a single letter into a square makes it a rebus. So, multiple letters, punctuation marks, symbols like stars and diamonds, and our usual Arabic numerals count as rebuses. 

Using regular letters, one per box, even when they mean different things than what they usually do, isn‚Äôt a rebus. The fact that they make up Roman numerals does not equate it with using 1, 2, 3, 4, etc. in the squares. If the Roman numerals made up of multiple letters had been crammed into one square, that would have been a rebus. 

What‚Äôs more, calling them rebuses in a column designed to help new solvers is just confusing and counterproductive. This is by far the worst column Sam has ever written, and I usually like what she has to say.

Marty, There are no rebuses in this puzzle. Several squares contain English language letters that must be read as Roman numerals for the Across answers. That does not meet the crossword or non-crossword meaning of a rebus. (Earlier puzzles using letters one way as Roman numerals are not listed in xwordinfo.com as rebus puzzles.) "Some puzzles require you to use symbols or to cram more than one letter into a single box." https://www.xwordinfo.com/Rebus "a representation of words or syllables by pictures of objects or by symbols whose names resemble the intended words or syllables in sound" https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/rebus

@Marty

Not a rebus in any way, shape, or form.  If you don't need solving assistance I'd suggest skipping the columns except for the constructor notes.
As noted in the xwordinfo.com site, the term rebus only applies to what goes in a box in the grid. Rebuses in clues -- as in 65 Across -- have never been "counted" as rebuses.
